required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Nomograms to Precisely Predict Conditional Risk of Survival for Patients With Laryngeal Cancer
clinical_study.official_title: Development and Validation of Nomograms to Precisely Predict Conditional Risk of Survival for Patients With Laryngeal Cancer: a Single-institutional Study

lead_sponsor.agency: First Affiliated Hospital, Sun Yat-Sen University

clinical_study.source: First Affiliated Hospital, Sun Yat-Sen University

brief_summary.textblock: Advanced laryngeal squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) remains a highly morbid and fatal disease despite aggressive interventions. Mortality is high in this cohort: laryngeal cancer affects over 13 000 patients in the United States, with over 3500 deaths annually.The results of the Veterans Affairs Cooperative Studies Program Laryngeal Cancer Trial and subsequent studies demonstrated similar overall survival (OS) rates for organ preservation protocols involving radiotherapy (RT) or chemoradiotherapy (CRT) when compared to surgery, with the benefit of preserving the larynx in a large majority of patients. As such, the use of RT or CRT has become the predominant initial intervention for patients with laryngeal SCC.However, the prognosis of recurrent and persistent laryngeal SCC is particularly dire.In this study,the investigators sought to identify preoperative predictors of survival for patients with recurrent or persistent laryngeal SCC in order to set patient expectations and address modifiable risk factors. Identification of predictors of survival may also identify patients who could benefit from novel therapeutic agents in a neo/adjuvant fashion. Herein,we examine a cohort of patients with recurrent or persistent laryngeal SCC after definitive RT/CRT who has undergone total laryngectomy in order to identify potential preoperative predictors of clinical outcomes.

detailed_description.textblock: Demographic, clinical, and survival data were abstracted. Death was verified via medical records and the social security death index. Primary outcome measures were OS (time from salvage laryngectomy to death from any cause), disease-specific survival (DSS; time from salvage laryngectomy to death from recurrent/persistent laryngeal SCC), and DFS (time from salvage laryngectomy to laryngeal SCC recurrence)

primary_outcome.description: time from laryngectomy to death from any cause

arm_group.description: status from radical operation to follow-up
status from radical operation to follow-up

intervention.description: The surgery treatment selection was based on the American Joint Committee on Cancer stage both of the primary and of the recurrence, as well as on patterns of local spread that were not included in the T classification and on the general condition and preferences of each patient.

study_pop.textblock: laryngeal carcinoma patients with radical surgery

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- laryngeal carcinoma patients with radical surgery
Exclusion Criteria:
- multiple primarry malignant neo-plasms

overall_official.affiliation: Affiliated Cancer Hospital & Institute of Guangzhou Medical University

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: First Affiliated Hospital, Sun Yat-Sen University
